facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 85 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 85 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 12, 1958 of Punjab High Court in First Appeal Order No. 183 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in First Appeal Order No. 183 of 1957,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated November 8, 1957 of Shri Harbaksh Singh, Member, Election Tribunal, Karnal, in Election Petition No. 249 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated November 8, 1957, of Shri Harbaksh Singh, Member, Election Tribunal, Karnal, in Election Petition No. 249 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 1, 1959 by SARKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. April 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-

facts.text: In 1957 General Elections, appellant was declared elected to the Punjab Legislative Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: ID the 1957 General Elections the appellant was declared elected to the Punjab Legislative Assembly.

facts.text: Respondent Gian Chand filed election petition declaring appellant's election void.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Gian Chand, filed an election petition for a declaration that the appellants election was void.

facts.text: Other respondent was an unsuccessful candidate made party to the petition but never appeared.

anchor.surface_text: The other respondent in this appeal, presumably another unsuccessful candidate at the election, had been made a party to the petition but he never appeared at any stage.

facts.text: Election Tribunal framed issues and recorded evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal before whom the petition came up for trial framed a number of issues and recorded evidence.

facts.text: When case ready for argument, appellant applied to Tribunal to dismiss petition under s.90(3) of Representation of the People Act, 1951 for non-compliance with s.117.

anchor.surface_text: When the case was ready for argument, the appellant made an application to the Tribunal for an order dismissing the petition under s. 90 3  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, ... on the ground that s. 117 of that Act had number been companyplied with.

facts.text: s.117 requires election petition accompanied by Government Treasury receipt showing deposit of Rs.1,000 in favour of Secretary to Election Commission.

anchor.surface_text: Section 117 requires that every election petition shall be accompanied by a Government Treasury receipt showing that a deposit of Rs. 1,000 had been made by the petitioner infavour of the Secretary to the Election Commission as security for the companyts of the petition.

facts.text: Appellant contended receipt enclosed not in terms of s.117.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytention was that the receipt enclosed with the petition was number, for reasons which will be mentioned later, in terms of the section.

facts.text: Respondent objected to application due to delay and need for evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent objected to the application being entertained because of the delay in filing it and also on the ground that it companyld number be decided without taking evidence.

facts.text: Tribunal overruled respondent's objections, scrutinized receipt, held not in terms of s.117, dismissed petition under s.90(3) without deciding other issues.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal overruled the respondents objections and held on a scrutiny of the receipt alone that it was number in terms of s. 117, and thereupon dismissed the election petition under the powers companyferred by s. 90  3  without deciding the other issues framed.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent went up in appeal to the High Court of Punjab.

facts.text: In High Court, appellant contended no appeal lies from dismissal under s.90(3), and order correct.

anchor.surface_text: It was there companytended on behalf of the appellant that numberappeal lay from an order dismissing an election petition for the reasons mentioned in s. 96  3  and that the order of the Tribunal was in any event right.

facts.text: High Court held appeal lies and s.117 complied with, set aside Tribunal's dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that an appeal lay to it and that the order dismissing the petition was wrong because the terms of s. 117 had been companyplied with.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is against this order of the High Court.

facts.text: Respondent deposited Rs.1000 and enclosed deposit receipt with petition.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the respondent deposited the required amount and enclosed a deposit receipt with his petition.

facts.text: Deposit receipt stated: 'By whom tendered- Gian Chand' and 'Name of the person on whose behalf money is paid- Secretary to the Election Commission.'

anchor.surface_text: The deposit receipt filed by the respondent companytained the following statements on which the appellants companytention is based- By whom tendered- Gian Chand Name of the person onSecretary to whose behalf money the Election is paid- Commission.

facts.text: Appellant contended receipt showed money paid by respondent acting for Secretary, not in favour.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention is that the receipt in this form showed that the money had been paid by the respondent acting for the Secretary to the Election Commission and number by him in favour of the latter.

facts.text: Supreme Court held receipt indicates payment in favour of Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: We are wholly unable to read the deposit receipt in that way. The second of the two entries reproduced above is intended to indicate the person in whose favour the money has been paid on whose behalf here clearly indicates in whose favour or for whose benefit.

issues.text: whether an appeal lay to the High Court from the order dismissing the election petition under s. 90(3)

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is against this order of the High Court. The first point that arises is whether an appeal lay to the High Court. The Act provides by s. 116A that an appeal shall lie from every order made by an Election Tribunal under s. 98 or s. 99 to the High Court

issues.text: whether the order had been made under s. 98

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention is that the order of the Tribunal dismissing the petition had not been made under either of these sections. It is quite clear that the Tribunals order had not been made under s. 99. The point that arises is whether the order had been made under s. 98. If it had not been made under s. 98, an appeal would clearly not lie.

issues.text: whether the word trial in s. 98 means that stage of the trial where evidence is tendered and arguments are addressed or the entire proceedings before the Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Chapter III of Part VI is headed Trial of Election Petitions . It consists of ss. 86 to 107 and covers the entire ground from the moment an election petition comes to an Election Tribunal till the final order of the Tribunal terminating the proceeding arising out of the petition before it.

issues.text: whether at the time of making an order under s. 98 dismissing under s.90(3) the Tribunal must also record a finding on corrupt practice under s.99

anchor.surface_text: That section says that at the time of making an order under s. 98 the Tribunal shall also, where the petition contains a charge of a corrupt practice having been committed, make an order recording a finding whether or not such corrupt practice had been committed.

issues.text: whether the treasury receipt complied with the requirements of s.117

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 117 of the Act the Treasury receipt has to show a deposit of Rs. 1,000 in favour of the Secretary to the Election Commission. There is no dispute that the respondent deposited the required amount and enclosed a deposit receipt with his petition.

arguments.court_reasoning: Case interpreted trial broadly in s.90(2); supports wide meaning in s.98

arguments.claim: s.90(3) dismissal order made under s.98 as at conclusion of trial; trial encompasses entire proceedings before Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: An order made under the powers contained in s. 90 3  brings to an end the proceedings arising out of a petition after it is made, nothing more remains for the Election Tribunal to try or do in respect of that petition.

holdings.text: an order dismissing a petition for the reasons mentioned in s. 90 3  is an order under s. 98 and is appealable under s. 116A

anchor.surface_text: We therefore think that an order dismissing a petition for the reasons mentioned in s. 90 3  is an order under s. 98 and is appealable under s. 116A. In our opinion, the case of Harihar Singh v. Singh Ganga

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal under s.90(3) concludes the trial before Tribunal as entire proceedings from s.86 reference to final order constitute trial per Chapter III scheme; order falls under s.98(a); appealable per s.116A; Harihar Singh wrongly decided

holdings.text: the order of the Tribunal dismissing the petition had been made under s. 98

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention is that the order of the Tribunal dismissing the petition had not been made under either of these sections. It is quite clear that the Tribunals order had not been made under s. 99. The point that arises is whether the order had been made under s. 98.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.90(3) empowers Tribunal to dismiss non-compliant petition; such dismissal is the order under s.98(a) at conclusion of trial; no separate provision needed as s.98 mandates the form of decision

holdings.text: the word trial in s. 98 means the entire proceeding before a Tribunal from the reference to it by the Election Commission to the conclusion

anchor.surface_text: An order made under the powers contained in s. 90 3  brings to an end the proceedings arising out of a petition after it is made, nothing more remains for the Election Tribunal to try or do in respect of that petition. Therefore, it would appear that it is made at the conclusion of the proceedings before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chapter III ss.86-107 headed 'Trial of Election Petitions' covers all proceedings; ss.86(4),88,89,103,106,107 treat entire process as trial; consistent interpretation required; Harish Chandra supports broad meaning

holdings.text: s. 99 does not require the Tribunal to record a finding on corrupt practice when dismissing under s.90(3)

anchor.surface_text: We are not impressed by this argument. If the proper construction of s. 99 is that an election petition cannot be dismissed on a preliminary point raised under s. 90 3  where it contains charges of corrupt practices having been committed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.99 applies when merits reached but s.90(3) allows summary dismissal without corrupt practice inquiry; similar to other grounds under s.100; no bar to preliminary dismissal; s.99(1)(b) costs still awardable under s.98

holdings.text: The deposit receipt complies with s.117 as it shows deposit in favour of the Secretary to the Election Commission

anchor.surface_text: We are wholly unable to read the deposit receipt in that way. The second of the two entries reproduced above is intended to indicate the person in whose favour the money has been paid on whose behalf here clearly indicates in whose favour or for whose benefit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Receipt states 'Name of the person on whose behalf money is paid- Secretary to the Election Commission' which indicates payee in whose favour deposited; standard treasury form usage; rejects contention of agency
